title.narrative: Local Governments For Sustainable Urban Development (Umbrella Project) Phase I

description.narrative:
Strong and capable institutions are critical for sustainable urban development. Improved governance processes are at the core of sustainable management and planning of cities and towns. Laws and policies have to be adapted to the local needs. UN-Habitat is working through this project to develop and reinforce a conducive and enabling environment, which requires adequate legal frameworks, political, managerial and administrative process, mechanisms, guidelines and tools to respond to the needs of the population and its local representatives.
This project will assist in a catalytic manner in advancing UN-Habitat's urban governance agenda and its norms, namely sustainability, subsidiarity, equity, efficiency, transparency, accountability, civic engagement, citizenship and security.
The present project operates at different levels 1) community, 2) municipal, 3) territorial (city-region), and 4) global, always in collaboration with the national level. It specifically focuses on local governments' adequate responsibilities and functions (multi-level governance), their capacity to implement and to control, community participation in the city decision-making process, and institutional accountability and transparency. The project addresses the issues in four main areas of work:
The need to develop governance arrangements at multilevel, with a focus on the territorial scale
Local governments are placed in a network of relationships and jurisdictions. Reinforcing their role, in a decentralized framework, with a multi-sector vision and at different scales requires a strong multilevel governance approach. There is a need for a common vision on the political and conceptual approach of multilevel governance and to unpack and translate this concept into practical tools for the use of local leaders. There is also a need to communicate successful strategies applied for others, to learn from other contexts either about the political process as well as its implications for public services delivery and to establish new horizontal cooperation between local governments.
Challenges such as urban mobility, employment and environmental sanitation, among others, extend beyond the realm of local governments and cover various legal-administrative divisions in the territory, which means that, in most cases they must be borne by more than one municipality. To ensure effective measures and to achieve positive results for the citizens, tax-payers and economic agents, coordinated action is required. Soft governance modalities, such as inter-municipal cooperation, allowing for two or more neighboring municipalities to perform together municipal administrative tasks and deliver public services or any other governance arrangements at the territorial scale could be explored. Sound territorial management is also a way to go beyond the rural-urban divide and to address metropolitan governance.
The need to strengthen municipal institutions by exploring other dimensions of governance
Local governments do not have a single relation with national or regional levels of governments and participation is not only a matter of elections. Looking downstream and at non-state actors is increasingly important to ensure a real participatory process and stronger inclusion of all in the city decision-making process. There is a need to identify new approaches and tools for renewed dialogue between people and institutions. Building on this approach, the use of ICT facilitates a two-way communication process, from community to local government and from local government to community. Smart technologies appear to be a tool to improve public service delivery, operational efficiency and ease intergovernmental relations. This can be specifically applied to youth, who are a large demographic in most urban centers and frequent users of mobile technologies. Despite their growing numbers, youth are largely excluded from participation in the policy-making and decision-making, leaving them socially and politically marginalized. Youthful citizens are governance game changers and Smart technologies are a lever and an opportunity to allow them to promote democratic public choice making. In return, there is a need to transform their contribution into better informed, more transparent and accountable local governments. In addition to e-governance, informal governance is another aspect to be explored. Informality is rarely considered as an asset and local governments often feel powerless when confronted to this multi dimension reality. A third dimension to be supported is the relationship of local governments with non-state actors and corporate interests, a relationship which is often misunderstood, implicit or unbalanced. More generally, these dimensions of local governance can inform broader researches and definition of indicators.
The need to ensure municipal financial sustainability with accountable leadership
Municipal finances are central to local governments, as their strategic management plays a critical role in ensuring long-term sustainability of local services. One key issue faced by local governments is how to expand their resource base beyond central-to-local transfers. Stakeholders are keen to integrate new ideas/tools on expenditure management, tax base identification, local tax collection, etc. In all cases, improved governance practices and enhanced accountability mechanisms (e.g., public transparency of budgets, customer service contracts for public utilities, adequate public asset management, clear monitoring of the performance of local governments) have become central to sound city government and municipal management. This project responds to the need to enhance knowledge and skills of local governments in the field of municipal finance, to allow them fulfill their responsibilities. Taxation requires both effective service delivery and transparent management to be sustainable and accepted by citizens. The development of tools to support municipalities in getting endogenous resources (local service taxation and integrating informality) goes in parallel with providing tools and how-to instruments to improve the management and transparency of local finances. This latter is a crucial need, as transparency and perception of local corruption is the necessary linkage between municipal sustainability and governance.
The need for political support to local governments and their associations through the post 2015 and Habitat III processes.
UN-Habitat and the Global Taskforce have been made coordinators, together with UNDP, of the global consultation “Localizing SDGs”. The LG Unit is aiming at getting innovative processes at city level and good inputs to the SDG definition process, in particular related to future "means of implementation". This process is also directly related to the campaign for an urban SDG, strongly supported by the Global Taskforce which brings together bringing Mayors, Governors and local government associations to raise their views and concerns at the UN and to create awareness on the needs of local government regarding the international development agenda. In addition, the preparatory process of Habitat III (decision making process in New York and in Preparatory Conferences) requires also full engagement and support to local governments. Habitat III will have to give solutions to this new role for cities and local governments. Both processes require a combination of expert meetings and the provision of materials, experience collection and technical expertise displaying how and what local government can provide for the achievement of sustainable urban development. There is also a need to ensure the follow-up of these international and political processes: the outcomes of the Post-2015 and the New Urban Agendas are likely to call for stronger implication of local governments, as essential responsible for their implementation.
The project objectiveis to contribute to sustainable urban development and local democracy through capable, resourceful and empowered local governments. The strategic result is that local governments will have adequate governance structures, mechanisms and resources to fulfill responsibilities and influenceurbandevelopment agendas atall levels of interventions.The project envisages partnering with various stakeholders at normative and operational levels to develop, test, evaluate and disseminate tools, methodologies and knowledge to reinforce local governments' recognition and capacities in specific topics mentioned above. This project will allow the coordination of on-going efforts in the area of urban governance throughout the Agency and will leverage resources with other ongoing projects. This project builds on existing workstreams within the area of governance and looks at developing more adapted approaches and means of operationalization for local and regional governments. As this is cross-cutting issues, each area will involve cooperation with another unit of UN-Habitat and/or relevant partners able to relate to and involve local governments.
The project will target primarily policy-makers at local and regional level who will be the end-beneficiaries of the project, as well as local governments associations. Citizens and urbanites will be the indirect beneficiaries of enhanced capacities (human, financial and institutional) of their local representatives.
